wikipedia_page.main: James Gerald Gulliver CVO FRSE FRSA FICE (17 August 1930 – 12 September 1996) was the founder of Argyll Foods, one of the United Kingdom's largest retail businesses.

response: *James Gerald Gulliver, founder of Argyll Foods

On 5 February 1979, he sold his business to James Gerald Gulliver of Argyll Foods for £100,000.The Guardian, 10 September 1998.</Ref> The deal also included a 16 per cent stake in Manchester United for Gulliver, who became a vice-president of the club.<ref> Edwards retired from the business world apart from his four-days-a-month consultancy position for Gulliver.Manchester United: The Betrayal Of A Legend, p. 119. He devoted his full-time commitments towards Manchester United and was at Old Trafford most days. Initially, Edwards' business retained the name Louis C. Edwards and Sons but changed its name in October 1980. Gulliver bought 500,000 of the family's shares at 5p each.Manchester United: The Betrayal Of A Legend, p. 117.

He then began working in the retail trade in the Argyll Group under James Gerald Gulliver and was evolved in the revival of the now extinct retail chain "Fine Fare".The Telegraph (newspaper) obituary, 24 January 2001 He rose to be Chief Executive of the Argyll Group from 1986 to 1998, including taking over the "Safeway" chain in 1987. He was knighted in the 1992 New Year Honours.
*James Gerald Gulliver, lately Trustee, The Duke of Edinburgh's Award Scheme.
*James Gerald Gulliver (1930–1996), founder of Argyll Foods
